title: Man who bludgeoned wife to death with crowbar jailed for life
text:
David Pomphret, seen in the back of an ambulance after killing his wife, has been jailed for life (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

A man who brutally bludgeoned his wife to death with a crowbar then lied about being at the scene has been jailed for life to serve a minimum of 20 years.

Computer expert David Pomphret, 51, hit his cancer-stricken wife Ann Marie, 49, more than 30 times in a ‘frenzied’ attack at horse stables they owned near their home in Winwick, Cheshire, on 2 November last year.

The Barclays bank worker, who was described as a ‘quiet man’ in court, claimed he had suffered a temporary loss of control and should only be found guilty of manslaughter.

He tried to blame the brutal killing on his ‘volatile’ wife’s behaviour.

But a jury at Liverpool Crown Court convicted him of murder last week after a 10-day trial.

Pomphret will serve a minimum of 20 years in prison for murder (Picture: PA)

Ann Marie Pomphret was hit over the head more than 30 times, the jury was told (Picture: Cheshire Police)

Following the attack, Pomphret dialled 999 saying he had found his wife lying in a pool of blood, ‘very dead’, adding: ‘There is brain and blood everywhere, and it looks like she has had her head beaten in.’

The court was shown video of the killer sitting in the back of an ambulance with his head in his hands telling officers he tried to do ‘mouth-to-mouth’ on Ann Marie, who lay motionless nearby.

Pomphret initially protested his innocence but was ‘undone’ after a speck of blood on his socks showed he was at the scene.

Sentencing him today, a judge described him as ‘an accomplished liar’.

Pomphret tried to cover his tracks by saying: ‘One of Marie’s favourite TV programmes was CSI and one of the things they always said is you can’t get rid of blood.’

He was granted bail but re-arrested four months later after police found the ‘airborne blood’ on his socks, which was dubbed a ‘huge mistake’.

Pomphret then changed his story, the jury was told, and admitted manslaughter, tearfully telling Liverpool Crown Court he ‘killed the woman I loved’.

Passing sentence, Judge David Aubrey told Pomphret he had meticulously tried to cover his tracks and may well have got away with this murder but added: ‘You forgot to change your socks.

‘It was a web of deceit and lies. In my judgment you are an accomplished liar.

‘She had defensive injuries to both her hands. She must have been pleading and begging for you to stop.

‘You had had enough of her, saw the opportunity that presented itself that night to kill her and did so.’
